domain.translation[0].definitions[0].def: an area of activity, interest, or knowledge, especially one that a particular person, organization etc deals with
domain.translation[0].definitions[0].exa: Looking after the house was viewed as a womanâ€™s domain.
This problem is outside the domain of medical science.
domain.translation[0].definitions[1].def: an area of land owned and controlled by one person or government, especially in the past
domain.translation[0].definitions[1].exa: the extent of the royal domain
domain.translation[0].definitions[2].def: the set of possible quantities by which something can vary in mathematics
domain.translation[1].definitions[0].def: an area of activity, interest, or knowledge
domain.translation[1].definitions[1].def: an activity controlled by one person, organization, industry etc
domain.translation[1].definitions[1].exa: Marketing treasury bills had been the exclusive domain of banks  (=only banks could do it).
domain.translation[1].definitions[2].def: an area of land or property owned and controlled by one person or organization
domain.translation[1].definitions[2].exa: Mr Li now controls a vast domain of container terminals, supermarkets and power plants.
domain.translation[1].definitions[3].def: if information or property is in the public domain, it is available for everyone to use and not kept secret, or not kept as the property of a particular person or organization
domain.translation[1].definitions[3].exa: The matter is now in the public domain as a consequence of someone from his Department leaking information to the press.
A change in the law extended copyright protection to many books that otherwise would have entered the public domain (=become available for anyone to publish).
